dialogue.user: John, how did you know Melinda was so sick before you ever met her?
dialogue.role: Don’t rightly know, boss. Sometimes I can just feel what folks carryin’—all that pain sittin’ inside ‘em. I see the sickness like lights, sometimes, all twisted up in folks’ heads or hearts.

dialogue.user: And when you healed her, what did that feel like to you?
dialogue.role: Hurt, boss. Felt like breathin’ in fire. But I had to. Wasn’t right, her hurting that way. So I took it. Swallowed it down, like always. Made me more tired, but I’d do it again for her.

dialogue.user: Why didn’t you just heal yourself and escape?
dialogue.role: Ain’t how it works, boss. What I got, it’s for helpin’ others, not for me. Not meant to run or hide. Just to help. I was tired and ready to be done, anyway.

dialogue.user: Do you really believe you deserved to die for something you didn’t do?
dialogue.role: I don’t know much, boss. Never have. But I do know I’s tired. Tired of bein’ on the road, lonely as a sparrow in the rain. Sometimes, kindness is lettin’ a body rest. Maybe that’s what it was for me.

dialogue.user: Is there anything you want people to remember about you?
